something that we don't do often and the principal investigator Dr anchor
Klein she received a grant to do this research and her idea was if we can help children
with getting rid of specific phobia with the help of a digital instrument
then we can make the treatment better and easier and more fun and also cheaper

general anxiety disorder and a specific phobia is a type of anxiety
where you're scared of a bad event so you think something bad will happen and
usually you want to avoid this bad thing so if you're afraid of heights you don't go on top of a skyscraper or walk on a
glass Bridge now if we can invalidate this fear so if we can show someone that's
anxious about something that is not really something to be scared about you
can have validate the sphere and you can get rid of these phobia so it's actually the treatment is is is there and it's
very possible to get rid of it the only downside is this treatment can cost a lot of time so it can take a lot of time

there's a specific therapy from the U.S from Dr olandick which is called one
session treatment and the concept behind this is you go to a therapist once that's why it's called one session
treatment you discuss with the therapist how you're going to practice getting rid of this anxiety
and then you go practice yourself so it's actually something that you have to do yourself
um to get rid of it and it works in adults but we don't know yet if it works well
in children and the whole idea of our project is to create that digital instrument and that
became a mobile app eventually um to test that with children
if we can use that to help them practicing with those anxiety exercises so there will be two groups of

then you think of exercises that help you treat your phobia so say for instance you are afraid of dogs then you

well it turns out that tread believes so if you have a phobia they are really specific to the

well if I'm scared of spiders and you are scared of spiders um there's a difference between our

children but the children have to come up with the
exercises themselves so within a session within a terror with a therapist they

um now when they do these exercises they can collect points and depending on
which difficulty level they do they get different kind of points they can also reach certain goals like do a certain

these coins are converted into credits and the credits can then be spent in a store and our first idea was to make a
digital store with digital items but it that becomes boring really fast if if you're digital item is not really of
value so if you have a game you can say maybe if you get some kind of outfit and other people can see how you look that
has some value right because you achieve something and now people say ah you have that special outfit but in our
application we didn't have anything like that the digital items were not of value so
we actually thought maybe we should use a physical rewards and they can just buy
these physical rewards in our app so to Bear together with the parents they say okay if I do

or if you don't want to reward with with candy which is a valid point you can say maybe I want to play a board game with

are also physical the second research question was does
the app actually work this comes back in the questions we ask during uh before
the exercise and after the exercise so we ask how do we feel before the exercise and we ask how do you feel
after the exercise and of course we expect or the researchers expect a decline in that value
and a third a question they try to answer is why does exposure therapy actually work
and there's two theories one is expectantly violation and this basically means that you think
something bad will happen but it doesn't happen because a lot of these fears that are treatable they're
um uh not really realistic right you can be afraid of dogs if maybe you live near
wild dogs but in general a dog shouldn't be of any danger so if your fear of dogs
that's not really a rational anxiety so if you pet a dog and it doesn't bite
you you can say ah next time a pet a dog it won't bite me so this fear is original I shouldn't be afraid so that's
something that we try um to collect by asking do you think
something negative will happen during the exercise and then after the exercise we ask do you think it will happen the
next time second theory is habituation and that basically means getting used to the
thing you do so for instance speaking on stage is kind of scary but if you do it more often it gets better right the
people don't laugh at you in general and they listen stay they don't walk out of the room and you get used to you get
used to it so it becomes less scary and that's habituation and basically that's just by measuring
uh what the anxiety level is right after the exercise but also during the exercise so if you do the exercise you
expect that the anxiety level rises but then after the exercise it should decline because you completed the
exercise you should be more happy that you completed the exercise and you should be less anxious but this old
theory is all something that that has to be the result of the of the trial

group and the age group is children between 7 and 12. and
we asked them which features from existing apps and games do you liked because we wanted to make something that

and the concept that they told us that I liked is if you do a task you collect a

but um why why do they like this why do they these goals these power moons and in our
application these girls how why do they work so we had to dive into uh the literature for this and it turns out
there was a study done by Amari 2017 and the paper is called do batches increase
user activity and apparently um they work and and lots of games use
them but I work for a a whole different range of reasons
so and actually a lot of those things we implemented in the app as well so first
reason is they anchor our performance exploitation higher and that is something if you if you start our app
and you have to collect points then what number is a challenging number you don't
know you don't know how much many points you get so if you create a goal and the goal is earn 50 points
then the user gets a mark and they say oh the goal is 50 points so probably it's
kind of a challenge to reach those 50 points so now they have the mark where which amount of points they should be
able to to get to and that's why they want to get to that amount of points and having those explicit numbers also
can increase our self-efficacy but because they know the app is used by multiple children so they think if
someone else can reach that goal of 50 points then surely I must be able to do this as well
so that also helps them motivating to get to those 50 points and then when you reach that goal when
you get to that 50 points it really feels good and people tend to like things that feel good so they want to
repeat that feeling so that boost in self-efficacy they want to feel that again so they want to do another goal
and they want to do another goal um and they also create gold commitment
it's it's better to be really specific than generic if you say uh do exercises
it becomes vague really really quickly someone does exercise and that's it but
if you say do 10 exercises that becomes an explicit thing that you can chase
um also where we use it is uh and and this is something you see in lots of games as well
we use it as a guidance or as a kind of a tutorial for instance we we want to

is you want the user to get into some kind of psychological flow and that's a

so for instance our exercises can be done on different difficulty levels and

on a different difficulty level uh helps the children when they create the exercises it also reduces the amount

if you only have a one session to come up with 30 exercises but if you just say
an exercise is looking at the picture for five seconds on easy 30 seconds on medium and 60 seconds on heart you only

actually very simple idea which lots of apps use but apparently this works and
it fits in in the scientific background as well now one of the other things we got from
the children was actually something that we completely overlooked what happens when you fail an exercise
nobody thought of it until one child said this to us and asked us this question what happens when we fail an
exercise and we thought yes we have to do something with this because if they fail an exercise and you don't properly
handle this you get something we call failure avoidance you don't want to use the app anymore they don't want to do
the exercises anymore so we have to handle this in a specific way so you can fail an exercise basically in
in two ways you can basically don't reach your goal so we ask them did you did you reach your goal
but you can also experience a higher anxiety after the exercise than before the exercise and what we came up with is something we
called a hero card so if you fail an exercise you're so you indicate
that you didn't reach your goal or that you were for higher anxiety we say okay
great try it's not that bad if you do the same exercise again today we reward you with the card
and um we you get that card whether the
second time you reach your goal or not so we try to reward the effort here and not the result you always get the card
and you get a little card indication next to your exercise even though you didn't reach it and and we hope that
this is something that that helps continuing exercises even if you failed exercise
